messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Dear John, Thanks for your assessment.  Yes, it is a Tokubetsu Kicho ninteisho. ... This gilded surface is actually a gilded copper plate that comes out.
messages.messageBody:
Dear John,

Thanks for your assessment. Yes, it is a Tokubetsu Kicho ninteisho.

> Interestingly, the seppa-dai is only gilded
> on the omote surface -
This gilded surface is actually a gilded copper plate that comes out. Underneath it is the same stylised seppa dai as the other side. It begs the question as to whether there was at one time a similar plate in the other side.

I regret the poor quality of the photographs - I took them hurriedly some years ago. Currently the tsuba is not to hand, being on exhibition with other swords and tosogu. When it comes back to me I'll take new photos.

Regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Dr John P Lissenden
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, December 08, 2006 3:47 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help


Dear Barry

I am sorry, but I don't recall seeing the images of your Namban tsuba
before and I am unable to find them in my 'in box'. Is a green paper
from the NBTHK 35 years ago the equivalent of a tokubetsu kicho paper
(or perhaps it has just turned green with age!)

Namban tsuba are incredibly difficult to photograph, and this
difficulty is compounded when the metal is dark. A tsuba of this
group with a plano-convex profile is very unusual - I have certainly
never seen one. It has the ubiquitous, symmetrical design of
affrontes dragons facing the tama jewel (or is it a lotus blossom?,
with lashings of gold overlay. The alternating, perforated design
inside the mimi is a commonly found one, as is the chryanthemoid
mimi. Interestingly, the seppa-dai is only gilded on the omote
surface - I sometimes wonder how well would the seppa sit on a seppa-
dai such as this. The kodzuka-hitsu is clearly a later addition.

The photographs are much too dark to enable any deatailed assessment
of the carving and undercutting, but it appears to be of quite good
quality.

Date? Who am I to argue with 1670, but that seems to be a pretty
exact attribution. Perhaps I would put it rather later - what does
the kanteisho say?

Regards, John.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@...>
wrote:
>
> Dear All,
>
> Whilst we are on the topic of Namban tsuba I have posted two (not
so good) images of my Namban tsuba that took a green paper at the
first NBTHK Shinsa in the USA mmm maybe 35 years ago. The obverse
(red background) is convex whilst the reverse (green background) is
flat. A polisher visiting once commented "a good one!!". Early Edo
period ca 1670, I believe.
>
> Oh, it's in my folder "Barry Thomas" third one on the first page
(sorry, no tiny url. Something else I have to learn how to do!).
John I think I sent you these images quite some while ago???
>
> Best regards,
>
> Barry Thomas.
.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Dear All, Whilst we are on the topic of Namban tsuba I have posted two (not so good) images of my Namban tsuba that took a green paper at the first NBTHK
messages.messageBody:
Dear All,

Whilst we are on the topic of Namban tsuba I have posted two (not so good) images of my Namban tsuba that took a green paper at the first NBTHK Shinsa in the USA mmm maybe 35 years ago. The obverse (red background) is convex whilst the reverse (green background) is flat. A polisher visiting once commented "a good one!!". Early Edo period ca 1670, I believe.

Oh, it's in my folder "Barry Thomas" third one on the first page (sorry, no tiny url. Something else I have to learn how to do!). John I think I sent you these images quite some while ago???

Best regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, December 07, 2006 7:46 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help


Dear John, others -

I've posted a photo of the interesting namban tsuba that John had referred to earlier. The motif consists of dragons and catfish, a shrine (with gold jewel peak), breaking waves and vines (?) in sukashi work. This large tsuba (84mm rnd. x 4mm thick) has Tokubetsu Hozon certificate. The poster is in Yahoo photos: http://tinyurl.com/yxt45h
in a file named: Ron STL Perhaps John wishes to elaborate on this tsuba a bit more?

John, I've just received my copy of your book, "The Namban Group of Japanese Sword Guards; Aa Reappraisal" and I'm looking forward to digesting your research findings which make up this publication. Interesting!

Ron
STL
.,_._,___

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Ron Thank you for posting a photograph of your beautiful, papered Namban tsuba.  At 84 cms in width it is unusually large for the group - only some 3 per
messages.messageBody:
Dear Ron

Thank you for posting a photograph of your beautiful, papered Namban
tsuba. At 84 cms in width it is unusually large for the group - only
some 3 per cent measure that or more, and the largest one I have seen
was 93 cms. It is also unusual in that it has two contemporaneous
ryo-hitsu, and that these are both hangetsu-gata. Does the smaller
one have sekigane?

The iron appears to be good, although the extensive carving on these
tsubas meant that the iron was never of very good quality. The
carving of the undercut karakusa and the surface chisel-work are
sharp and excellent. The plain, squared rim; the absence of OTT gold
overlay; the conventionally shaped seppa-dai and ryo-hitsu; and the
asymmetrical design all combine to impart a dignity that is seldom
associated with tsuba of this group.

This is a beautiful tsuba, and well-deserving of its tokubetsu hozon
status. I am hesitant to give a firm time period. On the one hand,
because of the introduction of better metal-working tools, those
Namban tsuba of a later period are generally the more skillfully
made. Conversely, those with conventional seppa-dai were often
earlier. I imagine that the kanteisho says 'Edo period'? Shall we
say mid-late C18?

Regards, John L.

P.S. I hope that you enjoy the book.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Dear John, others - I ve posted a photo of the interesting namban tsuba that John had referred to earlier. The motif consists of dragons and catfish, a shrine
messages.messageBody:
Dear John, others -

I've posted a photo of the interesting namban tsuba that John had referred to earlier. The motif consists of dragons and catfish, a shrine (with gold jewel peak), breaking waves and vines (?) in sukashi work. This large tsuba (84mm rnd. x 4mm thick) has Tokubetsu Hozon certificate. The poster is in Yahoo photos: http://tinyurl.com/yxt45h
in a file named: Ron STL Perhaps John wishes to elaborate on this tsuba a bit more?

John, I've just received my copy of your book, "The Namban Group of Japanese Sword Guards; Aa Reappraisal" and I'm looking forward to digesting your research findings which make up this publication. Interesting!

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Dr John P Lissenden
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 06, 2006 7:37 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help


Dear Patrick

Yes indeed - one of the Namban group and probably made by a casting
process in the early-mid C19. This group is characterised by its
openwork and undercutting; the common presence of affronted dragons
with the tama jewel; and the atypically shaped seppa-dai. All of
these are present on your tsuba.

I would have expected a tsuba of this type to be of iron, but some
were cast in bronze. Interestingly these are unexpectedly attracted
by a magnet, but the admixture of up to 30% of iron to bronze in
order to reduce the cost of the expensive alloy was not unknown.
Also, iron was a common inclusion in naturally occurring copper ore

Regards, John L.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Patrick" <donuil_dhu@...> wrote:

messages.subject: Re: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Patrick I hesitate to place an exact value on your tsuba; it is, ultimately, worth what another collector is willing to pay for it.  That might, on e-Bay,
messages.messageBody:
Dear Patrick

I hesitate to place an exact value on your tsuba; it is, ultimately,
worth what another collector is willing to pay for it. That might,
on e-Bay, be around Â£100-150.

Regards, John L.

messages.subject: Re: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you very much for such detailed information on my tsuba. As a sidenote, would this particular tsuba have any monetary value? Although, if it did, I don t
messages.messageBody:
Thank you very much for such detailed information on my tsuba. As a
sidenote, would this particular tsuba have any monetary value?
Although, if it did, I don't think I would sell it. I have grown
rather attached to it - it has a certain sentimental value - my
great-grandfather brought it back from the China station before the
first world war. He visited Japan while there apparently.

Patrick.

> order to reduce the cost of the expensive alloy was not unknown.
> Also, iron was a common inclusion in naturally occurring copper ore

> Regards, John L.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Patrick. Looks like a Namban tsuba, made of brass and possibly and finished in Shakudo, though I am not completely sure on the finish. It would probably
messages.messageBody:
Hi Patrick. Looks like a Namban tsuba, made of brass and possibly and
finished in Shakudo, though I am not completely sure on the finish. It
would probably date to sometime in the Edo period. So what does all that
mean ?

Namban refers to a tsuba school that specialised in Chinese styles or forms.
Shakudo is a mix of alloys (95% brass and 5 gold) that makes a very
black finish.
The Edo period ran from 1615 to 1868 app.

The theme is two dragons, intertwined in arabesques, and at the top
looks t0o be the sacred jewel of Shinto and bottom, some form of mon (
family crest )

I could be way off on all of that of course.

hope that helps a bit.

Cheers

Richard Turner

messages.subject: Re: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Patrick Yes indeed - one of the Namban group and probably made by a casting process in the early-mid C19.  This group is characterised by its openwork and
messages.messageBody:
Dear Patrick

Yes indeed - one of the Namban group and probably made by a casting
process in the early-mid C19. This group is characterised by its
openwork and undercutting; the common presence of affronted dragons
with the tama jewel; and the atypically shaped seppa-dai. All of
these are present on your tsuba.

I would have expected a tsuba of this type to be of iron, but some
were cast in bronze. Interestingly these are unexpectedly attracted
by a magnet, but the admixture of up to 30% of iron to bronze in
order to reduce the cost of the expensive alloy was not unknown.
Also, iron was a common inclusion in naturally occurring copper ore

Regards, John L.

hotobuc-ket.com/albums/-v340/donuil_-dhu/_DSC0031.-jpg

I think it may be bronze. And help I could get with identifying and
dating it would be briliant! Thanks in advance!

Patrick

Regards,

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich and readers, Thank you for the answer. I read on Mr Gilberts page about Akasaka Tsuba. http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/akasaka.htm
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich and readers,
Thank you for the answer. I read on Mr Gilberts page about Akasaka Tsuba.
http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/akasaka.htm
<http://home.earthlink.net/%7Ejggilbert/akasaka.htm>
I quote.

âAkasaka tsuba are constructed with a hard skin layer sandwiching
softer, inner layers. This can sometimes be seen on the mimi or in the
walls of the sukashi. I have not seen this technique used on either Kyo
or Owari tsuba â.

I took a hard look on my tsuba to see if I could see any layers. I took
some pictures of what I could see. I wonder if what the images
represents could be just that. Or the layer displayed simply is due to
patination?
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba5detail.htm
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba5.htm
<http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba5detail.htm>

You are mentioning that the surface doesnât look like Akasaka and it
might be a late copy. Do you mean as in shiiremono?

Could the surface be more suited for Tosa-Myochin which you are mentioning?

Here are some dimensions if it could help.
7.0 cm H x 6.8 cm W x 0.6 cm mimi and seppa dai

Thank you for your time.
Fredrik


Richard Turner wrote:

>Hi Fredrik, very nice tsuba and not it is not a Chinese rip-off I can
>assure you. Akasaka would fit, as would Tosa Myochin. I notice there is
>no carving in the hira ( surface ) usually the tea whisks ( 3 and 9
>o'clock ) have the brush ( whisk ) lines carved in them and the Ginger
>leaves ( 12 and 6 o'clock ) have usually 3 dots ( see this image
>http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/akasaka_tadatoki_tea.jpg
>)
>and 3 lines on them as well. The surface does not look like Akasaka
>plate to me, I may be wrong, it's quite rough and pitted up close. It
>could point to a late students work I guess, or a late copy, none the
>less, I think it is a late tsuba, as in the end of the Edo period sometime.
>
>Just some ramblings LOL, they may be all wrong.
>
>Rich
>
>
>
>Fredrik Persson wrote:
>
>
>
>>Hi all,
>>I would like to have some help kantei this tsuba. It was fitted on a
>>mumei wakazashi I bought.
>>http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba5.htm
>>
>>I have seen that Richard Turner have displayed some tsubas with same or
>>similar design. Would the description of the design on this auction be
>>accurate for my tsuba aswell?
>>http://www.double-dragon-ebooks.com/NihontoAuctions/QAViewItem.asp?ItemID=45
>>
>>
>>Would it be possible to determine age or school? Akasaka has been
>>mentioned for tsubas with same design. Could this one be an Akasaka?
>>
>>Any information is appreciated even if you say itâs a Chinese copy.
>>
>>Regards,
>>Fredrik
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>Yahoo! Groups Links
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Interesting painting (sword related)
messages.msgSnippet: The Noh play is: Kokaji (a blacksmith, an official title of Waki) Shite(Mae) a boy, an incarnation of Inari Myohjin mask doh-ji, jidoh Shite(Nochi) a fox,
messages.messageBody:
The Noh play is:

Kokaji (a blacksmith, an official title of Waki)
Shite(Mae) a boy, an incarnation of Inari Myohjin mask doh-ji, jidoh
Shite(Nochi) a fox, Inari Myohjin mask ko-tobide
Waki Sanjoh no Kokaji Munechika place Inari shrine (Kyoto city)
Waki-Tsure Tachibana-no-Michinari place a house of Munechika (Kyoto city)
Ai-kyohgen a servant of Waki dance hataraki
? ? time 1.4 h
Category 5
story Mae The Emperor saw a wonderful dream, and orders Munechika to make a sword, a messenger is Michinari. But he doesn't know what to do because he doesn't have a partner. So he notices there is no way except for miraculous power and prays at Inari shrine. Then a boy appears and says he'll succeed, and tells ancient myths.
Ai Ai tells about the story.
Nochi Munechika is waiting the miracle on the altar. And the fox comes and forges with Munechika, and hands it to Michinari and goes home.

Cc: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Interesting painting (sword related)
messages.msgSnippet: Inari as patron of sword smiths. Munechika, a famous sword maker, was ordered to make a sword for the Emperor, so he visited an Inari Shrine to pray for help.
messages.messageBody:
Inari as patron of sword smiths. Munechika, a famous sword maker, was ordered to make a sword for the Emperor, so he visited an Inari Shrine to pray for help. As he prayed, Inari appeared and helped him construct a sword of superb beauty. (Story from a Japanese Noh play.)

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Fredrik, very nice tsuba and not it is not a Chinese rip-off I can assure you. Akasaka would fit, as would Tosa Myochin. I notice there is no carving in the
messages.messageBody:
Hi Fredrik, very nice tsuba and not it is not a Chinese rip-off I can
assure you. Akasaka would fit, as would Tosa Myochin. I notice there is
no carving in the hira ( surface ) usually the tea whisks ( 3 and 9
o'clock ) have the brush ( whisk ) lines carved in them and the Ginger
leaves ( 12 and 6 o'clock ) have usually 3 dots ( see this image
http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/akasaka_tadatoki_tea.jpg
)
and 3 lines on them as well. The surface does not look like Akasaka
plate to me, I may be wrong, it's quite rough and pitted up close. It
could point to a late students work I guess, or a late copy, none the
less, I think it is a late tsuba, as in the end of the Edo period sometime.

Just some ramblings LOL, they may be all wrong.

Rich

>
>
>Would it be possible to determine age or school? Akasaka has been
>mentioned for tsubas with same design. Could this one be an Akasaka?
>
>Any information is appreciated even if you say itï¿½s a Chinese copy.
>
>Regards,

messages.subject: Tsuba help
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I would like to have some help kantei this tsuba. It was fitted on a mumei wakazashi I bought. http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba5.htm I have seen
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,
I would like to have some help kantei this tsuba. It was fitted on a
mumei wakazashi I bought.
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba5.htm

I have seen that Richard Turner have displayed some tsubas with same or
similar design. Would the description of the design on this auction be
accurate for my tsuba aswell?
http://www.double-dragon-ebooks.com/NihontoAuctions/QAViewItem.asp?ItemID=45


Would it be possible to determine age or school? Akasaka has been
mentioned for tsubas with same design. Could this one be an Akasaka?

Any information is appreciated even if you say itâs a Chinese copy.

Regards,
Fredrik
